N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 ยง 161.3 - New York State elections not controlled by Federal elections

State Regulations
(a) Examples of New York State elections upon
which Federal elections are not binding are those relating to: (1)
the claiming of the New York standard
deduction or the New York itemized deduction by a taxpayer who has claimed
itemized deductions on his Federal income tax return; (2)
the filing of a joint New York State
personal income tax return or separate New York State personal income tax
returns on one form by a husband and wife who file a joint Federal income tax
return; (3)
the allocation or
division of the New York standard deduction between a husband and wife who
determine their New York taxable incomes separately, either on separate forms
or on one form; and
(4)
the
allocation or division of the New York itemized deduction between a husband and
wife who determine their Federal taxable income jointly and determine their New

York taxable incomes separately on one form. Where a husband and wife claim
itemized deductions and determine their Federal taxable incomes separately, no
such allocation or division of the New York itemized deduction is permitted. (See section 115.10 of this Title.)
(b) A taxpayer's election as to any of the
matters listed in subdivision (a) of this section may be changed without prior
application to the Tax Commission, subject to the conditions stated in section
161.4
of this Part. (c) Other elections
for New York State personal income tax purposes which are independent of any
election for Federal income tax purposes. (1)

The election to claim an overpayment of New York State income tax computed on a

New York State personal income tax return as a credit against the estimated
income tax for the succeeding year is a New York State election independent of
any election for Federal income tax purposes. If a taxpayer elects to have an
overpayment of New York State income tax for a taxable year so credited, such
taxpayer cannot thereafter change such election with respect to the overpayment
for that taxable year. (2)

The
election by a nonresident person to file or not to file on a group New York

State nonresident personal income tax return is a New York State election
independent of any election for Federal income tax purposes. If a nonresident
person elects to file on a group New York State nonresident personal income tax
return, such nonresident person may not file an amended New York State
nonresident personal income tax return on an individual basis after the 15th
day of the fourth month following the close of the taxable year. Similarly, if
a nonresident person elects to file on an individual basis, such nonresident
person may not file an amended New York State nonresident personal income tax
return on a group basis after the 15th day of the fourth month following the
close of the taxable year. However, if a nonresident person's status changes in
such a way as to prevent such nonresident person from qualifying to file on a
group return, such nonresident person shall be permitted or required, as the
case may be, to file an amended return. Such amended return must be filed
within the time prescribed by section
687
of the Tax Law. (3)

The election by a nonresident member of a
professional athletic team to file or not to file on a group New York State
nonresident personal income tax return is a New York State election independent
of any election for Federal income tax purposes. If a nonresident member of a
professional athletic team elects to file on a group New York State nonresident
personal income tax return, such member may not file an amended New York State
nonresident personal income tax return on an individual basis after the 15th
day of the fourth month following the close of the taxable year. Similarly, if
a nonresident member of a professional athletic team elects to file on an
individual basis, such member may not file an amended New York State
nonresident personal income tax return on a group basis after the 15th day of
the fourth month following the close of the taxable year. However, if a
nonresident member's status changes in such a way as to prevent such member
from being able to qualify as an electing nonresident member of a professional
athletic team, such individual shall be permitted or required, as the case may
be, to file an amended return. Such amended return must be filed within the
time prescribed by section
687
of the Tax Law. (d) Any election for New York State personal
income tax purposes which is not controlled by the taxpayer's election for

Federal income tax purposes, other than the elections covered by subdivisions
(a) and (c) of this section, may be changed after the due date of the original

New York State personal income tax return only with the prior approval of the

Tax Commission, and only upon such terms and conditions as the Tax Commission
may specify in each individual case. Notes
